title: How many rooms did the average house have in the Victorian era? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don't think there is a meaningful "average house" in the Victorian era due to the class stratification. Houses could have as few as one room or as many as hundreds! The first working class back-to-back houses in cities had just a single room upstairs and a single room downstairs, and outdoor toilets. These were deemed unhealthy even by Victorian standards. Later terraces of the period had windows and doors on both sides, and usually two rooms up and two down, but still had outdoor toilets. This configuration was probably the commonest in the late Victorian period. Middle-class residences could have had anything from six rooms (including the bathroom and kitchen) upwards, although on average it would be unusual to have more than ten. Such residences would usually have a hall and a landing, from which could be accessed a dining room, a study and several bedrooms. The attic may have also had additional rooms to house maids or servants. The country manor, as occupied by the lowest tier of the aristocracy, the landed gentry, would have had more rooms, perhaps around 12 main rooms on average, excluding the kitchens and any servants quarters. These residencies were quite numerous in the Victorian era. Broomhead Hall, Sheffield, England, home of the last Squire of the Wilson family:  The seats of hereditary peers could have anything from twenty rooms to a hundred or more. The second image here shows a stately home in England called Wentworth Woodhouse. Relatively unknown, it is one of the largest stately homes in the world. It is currently the largest private residence in the United Kingdom, and the east front (shown in the image below) is 606 feet (185 m) making it the longest country house façade in Europe. The building has over 300 rooms and five miles of corridors. Wentworth Woodhouse, South Yorkshire, England. One of the Earls Fitzwilliam’s houses until 1979:

Fortunately many of us Brits still live in the 6 or so roooms in our Victorian houses but nowadays most of us have extended at the rear, filled in side returns and done loft conversions to make those houses suitable for 21st century lifestyle and tastes.
